text: Alright, let's get this list going again! I created a new playlist (Part 13). Isn't this soundtrack just... perfect? Pleasant, wholesome, memorable, nostalgic. Keiichi Suzuki basically composed for Mother and Earthbound then left the industry. I wonder if there are any other examples of games like this that have awesome music composed by someone we never really saw again.
author: SupraDarky

text:
Wow, I never knew that about the composer. I'm grateful for what he gave, even if he didn't stay long in the industry. The only other example I can think of for someone like that is Shiono Yasunori, who composed for the first two Lufia/Estopolis games and (I think) nothing else in gaming.
EDIT: Op, spoke too soon, though they're all still pretty obscure and sporadic: https://www.giantbomb.com/yasunori-shiono/3040-94327/
author: CulixIII

text: He's very successful nonetheless, he just wasn't very interested in the Games industry which I respect. But he made the soundtracks of many big japanese films, including quite a few directed by Takeshi Kitano (Yeah, the Takeshi from 'Takeshi's Castle'). These days, he's mostly active as one of the two members of the band The Beatniks. He seems to be doing alright, just isn't involved in games anymore. :)
author: A. K.-O.

text: Considering the development hell this game went through, I wouldn‚Äôt blame him for leaving the industry. Assuming these were the only games he worked on, poor guy must‚Äôve left with a bad taste in his mouth. A damn shame, but like I said I wouldn‚Äôt blame him.
author: Korji

text: Bomberman 64 is Akifumi Tada's only work in videogames, the rest is in anime.
author: Hawlo

text: Slightly reminded of Tim Follin, gives a slightly wistful feeling.
author: en

text: @CulixIII Shiono Yasunori is a great choice, even if he did compose a few other obscure games. The Lufia 1&2 soundtracks are awesome.
author: SupraDarky

text: @Hawlo I never knew about Akifumi Tada! That's too bad, Bomberman 64 had some great tracks.
author: SupraDarky

text: I don‚Äôt think that Suzuki was even a video game music composer by trade, much like how Itoi wasn‚Äôt a video game creator. it takes all types.
author: David E.

text: It reminds me of Michael Hoenig, he only composed for Baldur's Gate 1 and 2. Although he has had a good career in TV and films.
author: Pep Toni Castro Garc√≠a

text: There's also Module who made the music for Shatter and nothing else, as far as I know.
author: Beremor

text: Didn't the composers for Super Paper Mario also make music for that game only and then never again? They seemed to have vanished from the industry or at least from Nintendo
author: Lucas

text: There's Masato Nakamura, that composed the soundtrack for Sonic 1 and 2. He's very famous in Japan as bassist for the band Dreams Come True.
author: rerekiki

text: Brad Spear who did the ost to Shadow Madness. Awesome composer that I don't think did anything else

text: Many great responses here! Suzuki surely was not the only one in a situation like this.

text:
I wish Nintendo would put this and EarthBound Beginnings on their online NES and SNES services already.

Seriously, what could possibly be keeping them from doing it? They aren't MOTHER 3, they are already localised...
author: Lucas

text: Apart from a great launch lineup with the SNES Online service, Nintendo has been absolutely brutal with their releases. As much as I love Nintendo, their decision making when it comes to online services has always felt out of touch.
author: SupraDarky

text: I don't get the love for this game; I was underwhelmed with Earthbound when I played it last. The music is good, at least.

text: HE'S ALIVE!!!
author: Stickerbrushes

text:
The past couple of days have been rough. This was exactly what I needed today, so thank you. Earthbound is like a second home to me, and listening to this brings back memories and emotions of all the times I've played it.

 I've been meaning to revisit it again with all the education I've gathered from college and do a critical analysis. Maybe it's time to go back to the game again.
author: TimBagels

text: I look forward to your analysis then. Cheers!

text:
Excellent song for the postgame, both sweet and melancholic. Also an appropriate name for a song that has Ness and Paula travel around the world to.

Hoping that a Jimmy and the Pulsating Mass song gets in soon. It‚Äôs one of those Earthbound aesthetic RPGs and it‚Äôs done really well.
